conclusion: To find the work done by the gas when it changes from state B to state C, analyze the process depicted in the PV diagram.
The work done by a gas during a process is given by the area under the curve on a PV diagram.
State B: Pressure \( P_B = P_0 \), Volume \( V_B = V_0 \). State C: Pressure \( P_C = 0.6P_0 \), Volume \( V_C = 0.5V_0 \).
The process from B to C is a straight horizontal line on the PV diagram.
The process is actually an isobaric process (constant pressure) because the pressure remains constant at \( 0.6P_0 \).
For an isobaric process, the work done by the gas is calculated using the formula \( W = P \Delta V \).
The pressure \( P \) is \( 0.6P_0 \), and the change in volume \( \Delta V \) is \( V_C - V_B = 0.5V_0 - V_0 = -0.5V_0 \).
Substitute the values into the formula: \( W = 0.6P_0 	imes (-0.5V_0) = -0.3P_0V_0 \).
The negative sign indicates that work is done on the gas (compression), rather than by the gas.
The work done by the gas when it changes from state B to state C is \(-0.3P_0V_0\).
